document_title: Gallbladder sludge: Causes, symptoms and prevention
subsection_name: soi-bun-tui-mat.json_4_Complications of gallbladder sludge stone disease
subsection_content:
Sometimes, gallbladder sludge stones will disappear on their own without causing any symptoms, even without treatment. However, in the remaining cases, patients need to be diagnosed, detected and treated promptly to avoid dangerous complications, including:
If not treated early, mudstones can lead to gallstone formation, causing upper abdominal pain, and may require surgical intervention.; If not treated early, mudstones can lead to gallstone formation, causing upper abdominal pain, and may require surgical intervention.
Gallstones that form will cause blockage of the bile ducts. This is a medical emergency that requires immediate treatment.; Gallstones that form will cause blockage of the bile ducts. This is a medical emergency that requires immediate treatment.
Gallbladder sludge can directly cause or contribute to cholecystitis (inflamed gallbladder). If pain symptoms occur frequently or are chronic, your doctor will recommend gallbladder removal. In severe cases, severe inflammation can cause necrosis, perforating the gallbladder wall, leading to bile leakage into the abdominal cavity, causing biliary peritonitis; Most common in older people; Gallbladder sludge can directly cause or contribute to cholecystitis (inflamed gallbladder). If pain symptoms occur frequently or are chronic, your doctor will recommend gallbladder removal. In severe cases, severe inflammation can cause necrosis, perforating the gallbladder wall, leading to bile leakage into the abdominal cavity, causing biliary peritonitis; most common in older people.
Gallbladder sludge can also lead to acute pancreatitis, which causes enzymes to destroy pancreatic tissue. Inflammation has the risk of causing a systemic reaction, leading to shock and even death, especially in cases where stones are stuck in the pancreatic duct.; Gallbladder sludge can also lead to acute pancreatitis, which causes enzymes to destroy pancreatic tissue.
